commentBody:
Quite Wednesdayish, I'd say.

No STINKEYE, I hope.



Wonder how this one will play in 16A.
A fun, quick puzzle with many groan worthy clues.  I particularly liked the clues for FREEBIE and DEARSIR ORMADAM. Even some of the non italicized clues were punny: e.g. SOOT for flue symptom.
I finished yesterday's and today's in exactly the same time
Easy for a Wednesday.
WHERE AM I?! PB with no lookups!! Found it easier than yesterday. Delighted to see Mr. Avedon.
So who else started out with NORMAL in 16A?
Good for nothing was a great clue
There are no italicized clues in the print-out version of the puzzle, so I had trouble finding the theme. Glad I checked this column to see what I missed.
Had no idea about Parker House rolls, and it took a moment or two to figure out RENxAIRE for the cross, other than that hiccup breezed through in half my average.
easily sailing until the southeast corner: RENFAIRE was nearly the death of me, mixing a tricky pun with an obscure phrase. And I’ve attended Renaissance Faires!
This was fun!
As a Bordeaux fan, I object to the notion that a varietal is popular. That particular varietal isn’t popular as a “wine” in Bordeaux, only as one ingredient of the many wines from the region.

A breezy, gentle Wednesday—just what the doctor ordered. “STOP ME If You Think You’ve Heard This One Before” by The Smiths is now playing in many crossword puzzle-solving heads: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=SckD99B51IA

Sam said, "I loved this theme so much that I’m hungry for more examples of phrases that would suit it. If you have any, please drop them in the comments."

The only one I could come up with is [throw for a loss] = SNAKE EYES.

But I'm expecting Cat Lady Margaret to chime in with, oh, half a dozen great examples.

To Parker Higgins:  
DEAR SIR (No MADAM, though they often come IN SETS):

This fun puzzle FLEW by all too quickly, and as they say in PEORIA, TAINT FAIRE!  I won't ASKEW how long it took to construct it (and I'll ADMIT I did BREAK SEVENteen minutes solving it), but I think SAMOSAS an explanation for why she thought you could do the whole thing in rhyme?

Thought I would KEEL over when it was done so fast, but thank you, Parker, those AHA moments. I just wish there could be more.  

YET I'm not sorry to pour myself another STEM of MERLOT and fall to on the rest of my chicken TENDERS.  (STOP ME if you think I've had enough already.)

This one had me thinking really hard on the themers as I didn't want to simply surrender to getting them from the crosses. 
Even after I'd caught on, I still had to stop at each one to focus on the first word as a noun, and the strain I could feel in my forehead was completely worth it.

The smile on my face came from the legendary Richard AVEDON being so appropriately squeezed between a fine MERLOT and the opulent fashion implied by REGALIA. 
An artist, he was – and I, as a teenager, would dive into his exquisite world in the pages of Vogue, Elle, and Harper's Bazaar.

Thank you for this very creative and enjoyable puzzle, Mr. Higgins.

A stag is also a deer sir.

(This is not a pun you'll fawn over.)

PE_RIA crossing O_OHED was brutal for me. Both PEORIA and OOHED look like random assortments of letters to my Polish eye. I also only sort of understand the theme, and the column did not really make it fully clear. 

I enjoyed most of the puzzle but the theme was intellectually too intangible for my simple mind.
Fun one!
This puzzle had an "retro" feel to me, maybe something about the style of cluing?
Finally, our Monday puzzle. Two days late and a samosa short...
The number of brand related clues makes me wonder if this is a product placement exercise.

Stink eye is a look
Freebie is a good
Dear sir or madam is an open
Ski slope is a run (sorta)
but... 
How is regalia a fit?

More like an "outfit" to me.
Got on first and good for nothing were great clues. Ski slope took embarrassingly long...Super fun overall, though, thanks!

This puzzle felt to me like an episode of Mad Men or another breezy throwback to an earlier era. I FLEW through it, so that means there’s hope for everyone today 😆.

I have a vague memory of PEORIA being shorthand for average Americans. Today, it’s more common to use “Ohio” to mean any person, place or thing that is ridiculously basic.

I would have been done quite a bit earlier but I had ReMI for RAMI. Not knowing [fashion photographer Richard], EVEDON seemed as plausible as AVEDON.

Oh, I mixed up the Picasso for the Caravaggio painting and put crossword fave “oboe” on first pass instead of LUTE. 🤦🏾‍♀️ 

Oh, I am not missing MERLOTs one bit. The inexpensive, high quality wine here is fantastic 🍷 . Don’t miss it if you visit Portugal!

Enjoy the day ☀️

"Ah, a themeless Wednesday", I said to myself.  I've been hoping a home would be found for delightful themeless puzzles that are at an early week level, and that's what I thought this was.

Oops!

No italics in my printed copy, and to me, the themers looked like normal clues to my crossword brain.

Not to say I didn't like it.  I did.  A lot!

FULSOME does not mean abundant, no matter how much news channels misuse it these days. It means offensively flattering or insincere. Apparently we can't even trust the NYT to get it right.

And before anyone can tell me that language changes (it does so mostly out of misuse), this definition, as well as notes on this very misuse, comes from my American Heritage dictionary. A book, not an online one.

Strands Thread.  No spoilers if you please until after the View All Replies button:


Strands #318
“Thar she blows!”
🟡🔵🔵🔵
🔵🔵🔵🔵
🔵

Our very own Sam is today's constructor.

I was a STUDENT, but never a scholar.

Yesterday's ALEXTREBEK instantly brought me back to Celebrity Jeopardy on SNL. Thx for Debbie Downer today. Up next, down a YouTube rabbit hole.

Typical long Wednesday workout for me, and must confess that even when I finished I wasn't entirely grasping the theme until I pondered a bit. Even then wasn't sure I was getting it. Had to come here to confirm. No big deal. And... a quite appropriate puzzle find today. A Saturday from August 14, 2018 by Sam Trabucco. This one was all in the clues. One example: "With 7-Down, literally, neither wins nor loses" BREAKS Except that the answer to 7 down was OXES. Hmmm. Oh, ok - turns out that the implied trick was SEVEN down. But the S at the end of BREAKS crossed the down answer at 5 down, which was PRESSEVENT. Here's a shot at showing that: ______P ______R ______E ______S ______S BREAKS ______E ______V ______E ______N ______T So... BREAKS turns into BREAK(SEVEN) One more theme answer example: "With 1-Down, literally, downright dastardly" BADTOTHEB(ONE) You have to go look at it to really see it. Here's the Xword Info link: https://xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/4/2018&g=23&d=A I'll shut up now. ...

Holy crucivibing, Batman! Nearly the entire puzzle was referring to my dinner yesterday, a song I just heard, the city where I was was born… Eerie. Loved it! And here’s an absolute beauty of a song by Mark Knopfler. One of those I don’t think I could ever tire of… https://youtu.be/6RKKVQkRnTU?si=hk8VJGwyg_O9qf7n

The Parker House Hotel, origin of the eponymous rolls, "is a historic hotel in Boston, Massachusetts, founded in 1855. The current hotel structure dates to 1927." It is now run by Omni, so remember that for your next four-letter [Hotel chain] clue. TIL it was also the inventor of the Boston cream pie.

From the wikipedia entry on Parker house rolls: "The story of their creation has several variations,[2][3] but they all involve an angry pastry cook throwing unfinished rolls into the oven, which results in their dented appearance."

A pastry chef angry? Impossible!

Four NYT puzzles now for Parker, and each one has been uber-entertaining.  In each, the themes showcase English language quirks teeming with wordplay, puzzles which have simultaneously dropped my jaw and widened my smile.

Parker has a marvelous knack for finding these quirks; I don’t know if they just pop into his head or if he belongs to some quirk-study program.  But they’re terrific, IMO.

If you want to experience or be reminded of his previous three, go to the archives and check out 6/16/22, 5/17/23, and 9/12/24.

Today he also widened my smile with some lovely non-theme entries.  PREBOARDED, for one, felt fresh to me, and when I looked it up after solving, I saw why – neither it, nor “preboard”, nor “preboards”, nor “preboarding” have ever appeared in any of the major crossword venues.  A true debut, plucked out of the ether.  

Some lovely single-word answers as well: TENDERS (as clued), REGALIA, and the omg gorgeous FULSOME. I also loved column five – KEEL, SRS, LOOT – a palindrome sandwiched by two semordnilaps.  

Just an abundance of lovely in the box today.  Thank you, Parker, for a most splendid outing, and more please!

SAMOSAS, not mimosas.

Never a good idea to drink in the morning.

STOPME if you've heard this before but there were no italicized clues in the pdf version (how difficult would that have been?).

So this solved as a themeless for me which was no problem at all since the noun/verb switcheroo came naturally. 

Zoomed through until I hit the speedbump at FUR/RENFAIRE.  One of these days I'll remember how to spell the South Asian specialty.  I could offer that there is a Tamil Nadu version called *somas* but I ain't that smart.  

Great puzzle and thanks.

Impressive theme!  And overall a great puzzle.

A lot of really hard thinking indeed. Inspired, I tried to come up with another theme entry. I tried to Fish for answers, but could only Flounder. 

(I know it doesn't really work).
Seemed very simple . . .

What a fun puzzle. I smiled a lot. If I hadn't clung to "Foot" for 1D, it would have gone faster. However.

So nice to have a Wednesday puzzle that is solvable (soluble? -- note to puzzlers: immersing electronic devices in water is not recommended). Bravo, Parker Higgins! Encore!

A nicely clued puzzled that yielded steadily. I didn’t find it a themed puzzle necessarily. I got the drift without the aha moment that comes with a quirky or challenging theme. Seemed like good old crossword clueing and that’s perfectly apt for a Wednesday.

I continue to recover from bird flu. Don’t kid yourself as I did, it’s a monster. I woke up with a chorus of mewling kittens in my throat that I’ve been trying to move out for the last hour. And that’s an improvement over the last five days!

As I am of a certain age, all of my stories begin with STOPME.

ko is giving me the STINKEYE.

I try to tell her that all of you are on pins and needles till I post.... there goes that STINKEYE again.

Nice one Parker, thank you

In keeping with the theme...

Read for pleasure? 

Could solve to... SMUT

[Stop for fuel]  GASCAP

[Work for peanuts] COMICSTRIP

[Down for whatever] HORSEFEATHERS (meh)

Hurrah for artisanal intelligence, P. Higgins!

Guessed wrongly at the photographer/actor crossing, and another short streak met its end. Tried "E" before "A", and my streak was history. In retrospect, "A" makes a bit more sense there.

The theme was decent enough, and some interesting *words* here: REGALIA, SCAVENGERS, HAYS, FULSOME, SKEW, PREBOARDED.

Will have to start a new streak tomorrow. Maybe it will last through next week and I'll BREAK SEVEN.

Maybe I'm being absurd-even I can't tell anymore-but don't these two icons look alike? (The first being a portrait by Richard Avedon) https://harvardartmuseums.org/collections/object/337644?position=337644&context=special&id=12 https://davidbowie.com/1975-grammy-close-up
For the Mini today, The Sex Lives of College Girls clue incorrectly stated it was a Netflix show when it is actually an HBO (Max) show. Yikes
Perfect Wednesday puzzle to prep for the rest of the week! Thank you.

An interesting puzzle. I love FULSOME words like REGALIA and SCAVENGER.
HAYS on the other hand. What? We bale hay. We say we’re baling, or hay making. We also mound and turn the hay before we bale. Never have I used HAYS, or heard any farmer use that term in my hearing. Is it a US regional term? Again; what? Scratches head in bewilderment.
TIL PEORIA.
Esso and HBO as complete guesses before ARCO and PBS, not being familiar with the brand or the programme (note to @Charles; yes, I do still spell it with an ‘extra m and e, it being the correct way to spell programme).

as so often happens I breezed through this puzzle without ever even considering what the theme might be.  Got gold. I  feel bad when I miss the true creativity. On the other hand it's kind of a treat to be on the same wavelength as the constructor subconsciously if not consciously. Thanks for a very nice puzzle.

I was held up for too long by my misspelling of BERMUDA. I had an U for the first E. Which made sense in my mind for 35A. [Gig makeup?] Oh, yeah, MUGS. Because drag queens call their painted faces that they prep for gigs “mugs.” Oof, guess the start of RuPaul’s Drag Race Season 17 has been occupying my mind!

I like a good party, but I've never been a RAVER. A nice glass of MERLOT puts me at EASE.
Fine Wednesday puzzle btw.

Well, here are my goods-for-nothing:

“Works for me”
“Aim for the stars”
“Play for a fool”




PORTRAITS
ACADEMY AWARD
TWELFTH NIGHT

Can anyone see that clown through the snow-storm?
Anyone?

The emus have had my goods-for-nothing overnight, so with some trepidation I am posting them again….

“Works for me”
“Aim for the stars”
“Play for a fool”




PORTRAITS
ACADEMY AWARD
TWELFTH NIGHT

Fun clues, like 21A, made me smile.  We need that.  

Thank you!
Always good to see FULSOME properly used.
"Pretty decent" as George Carlin might say. Or "a place for everything in its place" as per my maternal Grannie. A very neat 20 minute Wednesday romp

Is anybody else having syncing issues (especially w/ Spelling Bee) between devices (iPad & iPhone) after updating the NYT Games app today?  My Spelling Bee reflects “Genius” level on my iPad, but shows the game as unstarted on my iPhone.  I’ve tried powering on/off & logging out/in.

Guessing American names again. Wrong again.

I crossed [San Diego pro] with ["Nova" airer]: cADRE / cBS.
Seemed OK to me ...
Don't BEt on the MEtS like I did! BEG for MEGS.
Did I miss it? When will the MEGA puzzle results be posted?

Fun solve - the italicized clues were satisfyingly clever.  

Only nit is the proper name Natick in the SW corner, neither of whom I was familiar with.

I grew up in central Illinois, south of Peoria, and my dad said the phrase "Will it play in Peoria?" came about because Peoria was the last stop in the vaudeville circuit. So if an act played in Peoria, everyone along the circuit had liked it.

Having spent time on farms as a kid I was curious who would ever think Baling is synonymous with Haying. The only use of hay as a verb I’d ever heard was feeding cows - we need to hay the cattle. 

So I tried umpteen searches for a source to say to bale and to hay meant the same thing. Nada. I did get results that definitively said they’re not the same thing. 

I get constructors like to stretch things, but shouldn’t there be at least one example of the usage somewhere in human history? Otherwise we can hay words to have any meaning we want. 

See? I just did it!
One clue brought this straight to mind: https://youtu.be/SckD99B51IA?feature=shared

Why isn't the photo showing up?  Weird!

Oh, the puzzle....this was a smooth, quick solve.  Worthy of a Monday, I'd say!  I did learn that Tarot cards have suits ....and one is called WANDS.  I don't know the others, so perhaps the other constructors could remember to fill in the gaps?!  

And we have a "Girl Sportscaster" named ERIN Andrews.  Someday perhaps that won't feel like a trick clue.  Ladies can understand sports as well as Gentlemen can, eh?  Who'd have thunk it?

Okay okay.  Just thought we'd like somethiing to fight about.....
How dare you?  Nobody likes sarcasm!  Shut up!  Same to you!
(Did I about cover it?)

Pretty day here.  Hard to believe that big swaths of our country are struggling with post-flood issues and ongoing fire-storms.  The  enormous Blame Game going on is helping no one.  We are all blessed by the workers *especially those from Mexico and Canada* who are fighting the fires and helping to contain them.
Anyone else going to have the Beatles' "Paperback Writer" stuck in their head all day now? Just me?
Nice puzzle with some clever clues.
I wonder what percentage of solvers had ever heard of RENFAIRE before. Am I in a  minority?
Ask for a lot -> reserve price

Definitely a fun puzzle today.  Many thanks to Parker Higgins.  

I am happy to see Will Shortz back.  I love seeing his byline on the puzzle.  But what has happened to Joel.  I have not seen his name in a while now.
Natick in the bottom left

Fun puzzle, on the easy side even, for a Wednesday. 
Two quibbles:
High school JUNIORS mostly take SATs, seniors only do if they scored badly the first time around and think they can do better.  Seniors are already applying to colleges (if they’re planning to attend in the next school year). 

Why do we use PEORIA to mean mainstream when Normal, IL exists???
And I thought "Nova airer" must be the brand name of a  type of clothes drier (airer). Oh well, wouldn't have known it anyway!

That was a fun one! I really liked the theme answers, though I did not fully appreciate it was a theme. They just seemed like normal clever trickery clues where you have to twist the words to a different meaning. I suppose normally those have question marks....   Anyhow, seemed like a lovely themeless to me, with really fun clues. 

"Open for business" had me confounded for a bit but was a delightful AHA! 

Plopped in FooT for "Partner of loose." at 1D at first—once again, proudly flying my Gen X flag! I'm not exactly a RAVER but, hey, let's dance!!

I was sure “flue symptom” would result in the ever popular SNOT. Half right. 
Welcome back eke and err! Good to see you.
Wonderful Wednesday wordplay!  Thanks Parker...you're on a roll!
NORMIE, ILLINOIS is not a place? I eventually solved on crosses but that's what I wanted it to be
Love that I knew exactly what clip that was being linked to with mimes playing tennis reference.

I don't usually put much stock in completion times -- I prefer to savor my puzzles, not race through them.  So I was truly stunned that I finished today's puzzle in 7:38.  I couldn't believe how much I was on Parker's wavelength!  Answers to his wonderfully-clued wordplay absolutely popped into my head on my first pass.  I'm genuinely sad that it was over so fast.  Please keep 'em coming, Parker!
a very good puzzle. clever theme and clues
I've looked at those italicized clues several times and am darned if I can see a theme there. They just look like good clues to me. What am I missing?
I'd  have thought  "Dear Sir or Madame" was an "Opening for a Business", not an "Open for Business".
This felt like a Monday puzzle.
Super fun wordplay.. felt like a while since we had a clever one like this, thank you!

Last night Jeopardy had a "Crossword Clues O" category.

I was so disappointed that none of the questions were "What is OREO!"

I know some students who are not quite scholars :)

(Yes I know constructor probably meant the archaic use.)
No one has made any puns relating 55D to the name of the puzzle's author, but there they are, just waiting, in the eye of the storm.

48D…Anyone else thought this was Treats? Treat yourself?

Maybe I have done that too much lately.
Great puzzle, although the RAMI/AVEDON crossing got me... I was sure it was spelled ReMI and I had never heard of this richard eVEDON but I was sure he was a swell guy

@Bill in Yokohama 

I filled the grid faster than a typical Wednesday. Still, today's puzzle took me 70% longer than yesterday's, but also 10% less than last week's Tuesday.
@Wendy Laubach I thought so too, and just recently I was saying the Tuesday was way too hard.

@Susan Avallon 

On Monday night, right after completing the Tuesday puzzle, I said it was harder than usual for a Tuesday, and people immediately disagreed with me.  Of course, others had similar experiences to mine as well.
@Hazel F My first on a Wednesday with no lookups and in 30 minutes. Made me think but was very doable!

@Jamie 

Not I.  But thanks for teaching us that town exists.
@Jamie At least two of us!

@TMD 
Make that 3...helps to live there!

@Jamie 
FWIW, that was the answer 5/15/1994 clued as [Illinois State University site]. Seems to me we’ve had a discussion here not long ago of “normal” schools from which that town got its name,  but I don’t remember the context.

@Hardroch 
Now I remember why there was a previous discussion of “normal” schools. It was back on 9/13/2024 when the clue was [Sch. In Ypsilanti whose mascot is an eagle, not another large bird], Bill from Detroit wrote in to point out that the Ypsi students only became Eagles in the 1990’s, and had previously been Hurons and Normalites. BA wrote in about the University of Northern Iowa and their student paper, The Normal Eyte. It always goes back to EMUs….
@Jeff that's odd. newspaper and online solve are italicized, but non-newspaper print version has question marks to indicate wordplay.

@TMD 
“A mischievous miss from Woods Hole,
Had a notion exceedingly droll,
At a masquerade ball
She wore nothing at all
And backed in as a Parker House roll.”

I first heard this limerick at the age of about fourteen, and found it, indeed, exceedingly droll. (Fortunately for my virgin ears, this was the most risqué limerick I learned at the time.)

@Wayne C

MERLOT is a "popular wine" and is, ya know, from Bordeaux. I'd beg for a comma in the clue, but absolute clarity is a bit antithetical to puzzling.

@Wayne C 
According to the website for Le Conseil Interprofessionnel du Vin de Bordeaux, the breakdown for grapes used in red wines produced in the region is as follows:
Merlot: 66%
Cabernet Sauvignon: 22.5%
Cabernet Franc: 9.5%
“Auxiliary Varieties”: 2%

From what I can tell, even with a wine that is made from a mix of several varietals, the majority of what one would be drinking would be merlot.

@Wayne C 

In my 20s I rarely drank wine, and never bought it myself. In my 30s I started purchasing and enjoying it, sort of. Now in my 40s I have actually begun to notice the varietals, places of origin, the fruity or oaky flavors: I can semi-coherently talk about some of that stuff to the people at the local wine shop! If the trend continues, I'll make a post like yours before I'm 60 😉
@Wayne C Agreed, however St. Emilion blends are primarily Merlot-based (vs. Left Bank Bordeaux blends being primarily Cabernet Sauvignon-based), so this clue wasn’t hard to get.

@Wayne C 

Note that the clue was [Popular wine from Bordeaux], not "wine popular IN Bordeaux".

@Wayne C I initially answered "claret" but then realized that is not a very "popular" wine in the US so switched it to MERLOT. Much Bordeaux is indeed sold as a straight "Merlot" varietal in the US, even when it is mixed with other varieties.

@Sam Lyons 

And just like that, I'm back in my beloved musical 80's.

Thank you for posting this!

(And a warm welcome back! 😉)

@sotto voce 

I was introduced to the Smiths a bit late in the game, ca. 1993, I think? But seeing STOP ME in the puzzle and the cover of Strangeways on YouTube sends me right back to a little music shop upstairs in a little Tudor on the corner of 9th and 9th in Sugarhouse (any of you GenX Utahns out there? You’ll remember the place) right next to Einstein Brothers, and all the Palladium-worthy albums they carried. And my first serious college boyfriend who hailed from NY (soo subversive…) and couldn’t believe I’d never listened to The Smiths before. And he bought me Strangeways. And I listened to Girlfriend in a Coma till me ears peeled off. 

RiP, B. He died last year while climbing a mountain to watch an erupting volcano. Some lives, even of short, are lived to the fullest. 

“Life tends to come and go
That's okay as long as you know”

The Smiths
@Sam Lyons It wasn't, but it is now! Thanks, great song.

@Sam Lyons 

Fantastic clip!  Loved me some Smiths, but I forgot all about this one.  Thanks for sharing.

@Sam Lyons 

Thank you for that story: your introduction to The Smiths, the subversive act of having a NY boyfriend (if I read that correctly), and the extraordinary situation of his death really transported me! 

Gen-Xer here though not a Utahn -- but your description brought to mind one of my earliest alternative music purchases (as opposed to taping off the radio-!), which I hadn't recalled in a long time. 

In the spring of 1984, while visiting my uncle in SLC, I purchased R.E.M.'s Murmur (on cassette, sadly) in a neon-bedecked mall. I can still picture the place! But I have no idea what part of town we were in... 

My first Smiths purchase came a year later, in Newbury Comics in Boston: Meat Is Murder, on vinyl.

Thanks for the earworm, and the memories!

@Sam Lyons 

It was probably just a mall, lol. To my teenaged mind it was very modern and urban!

Without attempting a flashback rabbit hole, 1984 sounds right for when neon colors erupted on the scene. I have a connected memory of returning after that break and working on an elaborate "doodle" in neon paints while listening to "Hear Comes the Rain Again" -- though I'm very likely collapsing the timeline! 

Music IS a wondrous doorway.

@G 

1984 was definitely neon!

I had a pair of shocking pink Fiorucci jeans that I would wear with a shocking pink, boat- neck, long sleeved, off-of-one-shoulder T-shirt. (With very big hoop earrings of course, and high-top All Stars.)

"Oh oh here she comes" Ha!  Lord have mercy. You could see me from a mile away and, for some odd reason, even as an introvert, I didn't seem to mind.

@sotto voce 

“Oh oh here she comes” made me laugh hard because it’s now playing in my head. The perfect song to instantly convey the zeitgeist of 1984. 

When I was 12, still in the middle of the 80s taste revolution, my mother let me buy a pair of shiny, faux alligator skin pants, mid-ankle length of course, and of course tight. A picture recently surfaced… I’m posing in them in the backyard… on a new bike… wearing a very, very brightly colored bandana, that hair—you remember the Brat Pack hair, right?—and oh, oh so much eye shadow. There’s also, of course, the de rigueur glint of the braces. 

You can just hear Cyndi Lauper playing in the background.

@Pezhead, haha! I did actually post a few, awhile ago…

The emus are enjoying them. We’ll see if they share.
@Pezhead -- [Throw for a loss] -- Hah!  Great catch!
@dutchiris SAMOSAS >> Sam owes us, excellent! I laughed.
@dutchiris -- Now this is a wow post.  Brava!

Mike,

Again today, your post is a work of hart.

@Mike 

You gotta have hart.

Anything for a buck.

Let the devil take the hind most.

@Andrzej 
So, you’re telling me that clue wouldn’t play in Dąbrowa Górnicza?

@Nick 

Nope. Neither would it in Szczebrzeszyn, Ćmielów or Przecław.

@Andrzej 
I immediately thought of you when I read the PEORIA clue! I’m of an age that I found it a gimme… but PEORIA could perhaps be designated the foreign solvers Natick.

@Darcey O’D 
*solvers’*

@Darcey O’D 

I'd have preferred if it crossed with Oreo 🤪

@Darcey O’D 
I'd heard of it, possibly my great age.

@Lioncitysolver 

I wish to one day see ARCO clued as a European climbing mecca 🤣. Never gonna happen, and probably rightly so, buy I keep hoping 🤪
@Andrzej and here I thought you would have wanted Arco, Idaho (first town lit with nuclear generated electricity) since you mentioned visiting Craters of the Moon just yesterday.

@Glenn Weinberg 

Those craters and Ketchum were the only two places we visited in Idaho, and pretty much all I know about it 🤪.
@Mr Dave Something that “fits” a king, perhaps?
@Mr Dave In current slang online, fit=outfit.
@Amanda I second your comment. It’s getting to the point where the whole word “outfit” seems quaint.

@Amanda

Thanks Amanda! Except now I feel old! 😂

@Pani Korunova 
Do they still have the wine caves is Villa Nova da Guia?

@Pani Korunova 

The emus seem to be on a rampage again. I replied to you remarking I found Mad Men depressing rather than breezy, with how nasty and/or miserable the protagonists/antagonists were. I wonder what the "moderators" took exception to... There is no way to know, is there? Meh.

@Pani Korunova 

Mad Men, breezy? I tried watching that series but all of those people were so nasty or miserable - or both! - I just couldn't take it: it was making me feel depressed 🤣

@Andrzej But the clothes ! And the hairstyles! Took me straight back to my childhood, when it was a great treat to accompany my mother to the beauty parlor on Saturday morning. I still marvel at how women slept  with those beehives and managed to keep them neat for seven whole days.

@Teresa I fear your American Heritage dictionary definition of fulsome is itself an example of how language changes over time. Fulsome originates in Middle English, full+some, meaning...abundant. You of course are not wrong in your defintion, although it is the later of the two. In future, I recommend the Oxford English Dictionary if you are concerned with original meanings. Cheers from the UK!
Teresa, ...and M-W shows both definitions, notes the changes over time, warns of the ambiguity, but doesn't take sides. https://merriam-webster.com/dictionary/fulsome
@Katie - good of you to make such nice distinctions…

@Teresa 

The clue was actually [Overly abundant] which is exactly right for FULSOME. The flattering/insincere connotation comes from the overabundance, when it's applied to praise or compliments or apology.

As my OED says:
"... offending from excess or want of measure or from being ‘over-done’ ..."

But I've just had a rather fulsome lunch, and need a bit of a lie down.

@Katie You state your opinion on the purpose of dictionaries very confidently.  However, this has not always been the case, and certainly 'Dr. Johnson would not have agreed.  The trouble is that many learners would like to use dictionaries to improve their English.  In real life, people are judged by the way they speak, and sounding uneducated can have real negative consequences.  I liked the "usage panel" in my old American Heritage dictionary, which gave users an idea of what usages were controversial or considered unacceptable by "careful speakers," as I believe they were called.

@nash.mark 

My husband (a teacher) told our
children never to complain about
homework or school
because

school derives from *schola*
which means(meant?) 
*leisure.*

Only the wealthiest could afford
to spend their days reading and
lounging and learning.

Everyone else was working the land and
could never imagine such a life of ease.

So, if you were a student,
you - in effect - were a scholar.


That’s my story and I’m sticking to it.

@CCNY 

Etymologically, if you go to school, that makes you a scholar, but when I heard it used in some New York City public schools to refer to any of their students, from the valedictorian down to the one who threw spitballs from the back of the room, I cringed.  It had an air of (unintended) sarcasm to it...some of those students were certainly far from "scholars" the way we use the word these days.

@Steve L What was the Across Lite fiasco?

@Steve L

 I don't print the newspaper version because I am a cheapskate and don't want to use up my toner. The version I print lets you use the ink saver option.  Even though I select draft copy for the newspaper version, it comes out very dark.  If someone could tell me how to change that, I would be happy to switch over.
@Nancy J. Also, if you print the newspaper version it includes the solution to the previous puzzle. That squishes the clues and puzzle to a smaller version that’s pretty tough on these old eyes.

@Nancy J. 

You likely have already tried this  but a workaround is to download the Newspaper Version pdf rather than printing it directly, open that doc in Adobe and fiddle with the printer settings there.  Selecting "Save ink/toner" will lighten the image up a bit.  

And agree with Tom that the answers to the previous day's puzzle takes up too much real estate. 

As Steve says the Newspaper Version is sometimes the last resort for us "dead tree" folks.  In the past, in a fit of pique, I've refused to do the puzzle on those days, but I'm over that now.  :)

@Rachel 

As I recall NYT stopped supporting the xword puzzles in the Across Lite online solving format, quite suddenly I think, which caused a tremendous hue and cry in the comments for some time.  Was several years ago if not longer.

@John Carson 

Yes. Across Lite is a format that could only reproduce very ordinarily formatted puzzles. It was available as an option many years ago back when there were few other options for online solving. (The NYT’s own interface/app wasn’t running yet.)

Once the NYT online version was available for several years, with both it and Across Lite provided, the Times stopped offering AL as a solving option. 

Many of the commentariat went ballistic. I tried to persuade them to switch to the NYT’s own version, but they had their quirky reasons why they didn’t want to. 

I also discovered an add-on called Crossword Scraper that would still allow them to download the puzzle in AL through this third party, but that was apparently too much for these solvers to handle. 

Eventually, the ruckus died down and everyone adjusted, as the NYT was counting on. 

I’ll add that there was another third-party app, Puzzazz, that was able to duplicate unusual puzzles just like the newspaper had them, which the NYT’s own interface couldn’t, but the NYT in their wisdom decided to end their permission for that app to grab the puzzles. Probably related to ad views.  That was the one I was sorry to see go, but that’s when my NYT streak started.

@Barry Ancona 

"Cadre" has a fairly common singular usage, for an office-bearer, particularly a political one. Primarily relates to Communist organizational diagrams, admittedly. But it was perfectly possible, as far as I was concerned, that "pro" referred to a multiperson organization, in which case the plural cadre would have been fine. It's not a usage I'm familiar with in BrE, but one has to allow a little rattle room when solving in a different dialect.

[Scottish pro] would mean about as much as [San Diego pro] to me. Which is to say, nothing beyond the probability that it related to someone who was good at their job, or got paid for doing something many people do for free.

(Just FYI, there are many reasons for Rangers and Celtic football clubs to impinge on the consciousness of even those of us who don't take an interest in sport---they've recently been making national news headlines, again, for reasons essentially unrelated to sport.)

Tom, Crossword clues are hints to and need not be synonyms of answers. I had no problem with [Does some baling] as a hint for HAYS. "Haying basically involves four steps: Mowing (or cutting), tedding, raking, and baling." https://shelburnefarms.org/about/news-and-stories/haying-101

@Tom R - I grew up in a town with several dairy farms, one of which was run by a childhood friend's family, so I spent some time there. The usual definition of the very "hay" to me was "to harvest/cut/mow hay." I had never heard of it meaning "to feed hay to cows" So I went to that googles and looked it up. Indeed, there is a transitive meaning that is "To feed with hay" So, today I learned something! Thank you for that. Oh, wait -- there is an intransitive meaning too, which aligns with the usage I was familiar with. And more: It is not just mowing, it, but also "to cut, cure, and store hay" I would think that the "storing" part could include baling. Heck, modern haying machined https://merriam-webster.com/dictionary/hay Remember: it's a crossword, not an agricultural treatise. And there could, perhaps, be regional differences in how the word is used.

Well, I was in the middle of editing when I hit "submit" -- I hate it when that happens! 

Barry found a great example of what I clumsily was trying to express. 

Carry on!

I was feeling doubtful about this line of reasoning, so I tried it out in an analogous but more easily recognized context: [Caroms] for SHOOTSPOOL. 

This cluing here seem fine and my doubts were allayed. 

However, because making a carom shot is just one possible way to shoot pool rather than a standard part of the game, I wondered if this might not be analogous after all, and if maybe the clue here would have to be [Caroms, say] or something like that. 

Then I started wondering about the different cluing relationships that exist for single-phrase clues (i.e., unqualified single-word clues and phrases that behave like single-word clues): 

- synonyms certainly ([Plead] for BEG) - -
- sometimes subclasses (see HAYS) 
- conversely, categories (SCAVENGERS if the clue had just been [Hyenas])

But then what other relationships are possible? 

All of which is to say, I see my path slowly slouching toward construction. My wife and other supervisors in my life would kill me if I picked up another hobby right now, but it's good to have some kind of plan for retirement, right?

@Josh Go for it!
Anyone who can sneak in a Yeats reference is AONE with me.

@Mean Old Lady The four suits of a tarot deck are wands, swords, cups (or chalices), and coins (or pentacles): they correspond to clubs, spades, hearts, and diamonds, respectively, of our usual poker deck. Each suit has number cards from ace thru ten, but four face cards--page, knight, queen, and king. In addition, there are 21 numbered picture cards--the Major Arcana (we just had that in a puzzle, last week, as I remember)--with images like The Magician (I) and The World (XXI). The Major Arcana are sometimes referred to as the Greater Trumps. Just so you know. Also, a Fool which belongs to none. Just so you know. So, seventy-six total. Of course, there's a lot of variation, both historical and geographical. In English speaking places, the tarot is used primarily for cartomancy (fortune-telling), but I understand that in some European countries they're primarily used for games specific to that deck. Most of the popular images of tarot cards--especially the arcana major--originate with the Rider-Waite-Smith deck designs (first published 1909--if you can use the verb "publish" in this context), which itself has an interesting history. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rider%E2%80%93Waite_Tarot

Stephen, 

An "open" is an opening
(e.g., cold open for Saturday Night Live).

@Barry Ancona 

Dear Barry,

To my ear,  "Dear Sir or Madam" is an opening, not an open. It is the opening of a letter or other written communication. It is this  phrase, and not the word "open", that  I wish to discuss. (I'm sorry if  this wasn't clear). You can say, " 'Dear Sir or Madam' is how the letter opens" but not  "the open of the letter says 'Dear Sir or Madam'. At least not IMHO. (Of course you can say whatever you want!).  But anyhoo.

Cheers,

Stephen
